12oz bottle, 2011 vintage - Thumbprint series.  Pours a crystal clear, light red color with no head.  Aroma is fruity, cranberry.  Medium on the palate with light carbonation.  Flavor is sweet up front, cranberry, with a nice tart cranberry finish.  Easy to drink and very complex.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2011 Slight Cranberry aroma. Light red, pours with slight white head that totally fizzled off to nothing.Sparkling clear and refreshing tasting. This is my favorite of the New Glarus fruit beers. Fresh Cranberry taste with a hint of oak and vanilla, perfect level of carbonation. Very sweet at first which gives way to bitterness and doesnt linger as long as New Glarus other fruit beers, perfectly balanced between sweet and bitter. Wine lovers will take to it well. My favorite fruit beer.

Found at the brewery 7/2/2011. A pink hued brew pours out of the bottle topped with a thin, bubbly white head. Aroma has a modest cranberry tartness to start with some presence of a lighter acidic, oaky and sweet berry flavors at the end. Flavor has the cranberry tartness coming out first. A light sourness kicks in the middle and mellows out the cranberry tartness as well as allowing some oaky and light acidic notes to come in later. Body has a lot of carbonation with a mild dryness from the tart/sour/acidic combination. Overall a pretty nice brew with a definitely unique flavor. My one wish is that the cranberry and sourness were slightly stronger.

Reviewed from notes.

Pours an amber-red color with a slight off white head and some pretty decent retention. Nose is strong cranberry with a bit of acetic and lactic character. The taste is somewhat creamy and sweet with noticeable levels of cranberry as well as hints of wood and some acetic and lactic character. The sourness is just right and blends quite well with the fruit. Drinks really well when young and Id like to see how it ages.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-29-2010

RBSG 2010 - Pours hazy orange with a lingering head and a tart, fruity aroma.  The flavor is really tart and sour with flavors of dark fruit and an acidic finish.  Its medium bodied and very interesting.  Very good.  The only small downside was that it was a little too acidic for me.

The beer pours a white zinfinadal red with no white head. The beer is very clear with no lacing.

The aroma is all alcohol with some light cranbic at the end. 

The taste is light at the end there is alcohol. There is a little sweet cranberry to it.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2011 Bottle in Iowa City hotel room. Red tinted orange body with a slight off white head. Oak and red fruits with a touch of sourness in the nose. Delicious sour cranberry flavor on a fairly light oak flavor. Quite carbonated. Tart cranberry finish. Excellent!!

Tasted on 3/19/11 from a 12oz bottle purchased at Discount Liquors.  Pours cloudy blood-orange with an average pink tinted head that recedes fairly quickly to uneven lace and a thin collar.  The nose is sweet fruits with baking spices, tart cranberry, kids vitamins, vanilla, sour citrus, and oaky cinnamon.  The flavor is lightly sweet with vanilla, fruity, tart cranberry, sour citrus, baking spices, including cinnamon, and light vinegar.  The body is light, but somewhat oily, with nearly sparkling carbonation and a long tart finish with baking spices and a nice amount of oak tannins.
Bottle at Papsøs - Thanks. Clear amber - white head. Vanilla, wooden, oakey, light acid, sourish, dryness, cranberries, peppery, light sweet notes.

Bottle at Papsø.
Clear amber coloured with a medium sized off-white head.
Fruity and light acidic aroma of berries.
Fruity flavour of oak, vanilla and berries.
Sweet and oaky finish.

clear orange, small white head.
spicy aroma, dusty, perfumey.. faint fruity.
flavor is dry, red fruity,sourish, nice.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of daknole. Pours a deep golden with a slight haze and an off-white head. Sweet fruity aroma with a distinct vanilla oakiness. Medium body, sweet berry notes, again sweet vanilla and oak perfectly balanced by a slight tartness. No real hoppiness. Very nice. 150311

got in a recent trade from Lou, thanks LouMan!! .. Pours a deep tawny red tan .. . wow, this a fun brew . . light light funk notes, a touch of wood with a crazy good dose of cherry and raspberries . . a really nice and simple sipper from NG! .. . aha, sure, sure..

This thing pours a definite shade of rose, with underlying amber - but barely. It is definitely light reddish, small white head around the edges that leaves little lacing. The color of this beer is almost like a wine cooler.
Oak, oak and oak. I get a slight fruit in the nose, but it is overpowered quickly with oak. I opened this and thought I felled a tree.
Oak up front. A little piney, which is weird. Slight tart green apple. I dont really get the cranberry taste. Just the sensation of tartness. I was really hoping for a bit of cranberry to overpower the oak, but didnt happen. Almost tastes like a bourbon. But not as strong. And it isnt all that bad, unexpectedly.
Tartness stays in the mouth, both from the fruit and the oak. The oak stays longer, making it seem as if you took a bite out of a barrel. Low carbonation makes it seem like it has more mouth-feel than is really there.
A little hard to drink a whole 12oz. bottle, but it is surprisingly good. And has grown on me over the course of the bottle. I still would only drink one every now and then, but wouldnt push it away if offered it. I just wont be seeking it out to buy, or trade. Overall a decent unique beer. Keep it up New Glarus.

Wasnt too excited about the fact that the Eisbock was ditched for this, but I figured Id give it a go anyways.

Pours into my Champagne flute with a papaya mango glisten and a small soft white head.

Smell is pretty funky. I smell hits of cranberry, wax, oak, and sourness.

Taste is pretty funky too. Very large farmhouse style presence. Not too tart or sour, pretty sweet actually. Very oaky, which is rigid against the cranberry taste, it doesnt work for me. The is a ripe fruit sweetness about this that irks me to, maybe a bit too wine like.

Overall it isnt what I enjoy in this style, their other fruit beers are certainly better. It isnt tart enough for a cranberry beer and just seems overly funky despite being very fresh. On the other hand it is very light and easy to suck down. NG: Go back to Eisbock.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-11-2009 02:42:50
Lushawn is a NG god.  OMFG.  Nose is sour and cinnamin and tart fruit (duh, cranberries!).  Massively complex.  Smooth leather wildness way in the back.  Super good.

12oz bottle. Pours a   Hazy amber with just a touch of head. Moderate carbonation.  Cranberry definitely comes through.  Mild swetness with a crisp tart bite but not to the point of mouth Pickering sour.  Excellent.

bottle. murky, orange pour with minimal head. aroma of sour, tart cranberry relish, orange peel, light leather and oak. a beautiful, sweet and sour, tangy lambic. very flemish in nature, as this reminds me of some of the top dogs out their in that category (rodenbach grand cru, la folie, etc....seriously)..cranberry comes out oh-so-perfectly...tart, crisp, subtly sweet, and cranberry soaked oak...this beer is autumn in a bottle, and ranks up there with New Glarus other fruits...amazing

Poured into a tulip. Thanks to alcstradamus for this one.

4.0 A: Clear orange red color. One and a half fingers of frothy head with decent retention and a touch of lacing.

4.0 S: Tart cranberries with some underlying acidity. Noticeably musky with lots of woodiness and a touch of tannic astringency.

4.0 T: Cranberries are more pronounced in the taste. Surprisingly, this beer isnt super tart. I figured wild bugs mixed with cranberries would be crazy tart. Actually, it has a decent sweetness to it. Slight lactic acid, but not any acetic. Well made, but lacking in complexity.

4.0 M: Lighter body. Good spritzy carbonation. Mouth puckering tartness on finish.

4.5 D: Once again, NG doesnt disappoint. Very drinkable and smooth with moderate pucker factor.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-09-2010 20:43:56

sample at sour tasting.  Pretty good beer.  the cranberry and cherry are help up well, slight medicine taste but not too bad.  vanilla and oak are hiding in the back.  not as tart or sour as expected.

Bottle...  Poured a golden/copper-orange with an off-white head.  The aroma had lots of cranberry fruit with some sweet tart tones.  Dry palate, thin, with noticeable yeast depth.  Lots of fresh cranberry and other fruit flavors.  Sweet like Capris Sun with fresh fruits all the way to the finish.

Another thank you to my cousin, and to his contact in Wisconsin.  Brass pour.  Fruity, lightly sour aroma.  Very cider-like.  I can taste cranberry, cinnamon, grape wine, lemon, cranberry-apple cider.  Farm stand fresh, like other NG releases.  Very nice.

12 oz bottle. Pours a mostly clear, reddish pink color and topped by a smooth head of beige colored foam that slowly recedes to a thin film. The head leaves some skinny lines of lacing behind on the glass. The aroma shows fresh cranberries and cherries along with some sweet vanilla bean. The berries smell fresh and juicy and stay away from the medicinal smell that plenty of fruit beers suffer from. The flavor follows with the fresh, juicy cherries and cranberries showing mostly sweet, but there are some tart berries in the background as well. The vanilla beans seem to tie the fruits together and smooth things out. Medium bodied with lively carbonation that leads to sweet tart berry finish. This is a nice fruit beer to be enjoyed in small doses. Dan Carey once again shows he is the master of all things fruit beers.
Light brown color.  Nice aroma, sour, with some balsamic.  Flavor has vanilla, sugar, fruit, though I would have guessed cherry if I didnt know better.  A very nice fruit beer.

The aroma was strong fruit with cranberry and strawberry notes, the appearance was an awesome amber color with some interesting red tints and red tinted foam.  The flavor was sweet and fruity with lots of strawberry and cranberry notes but not overly acidic.  The palate was lively carb and good body. Overall a good fruit beer with some excellent qualities, well done.

Bottle at Where the Wild Beers Are. Light amber pour with bubbly white head. Great aroma of oak, cherry, and vanilla extract. Even better flavor: sweet vanilla, oh so sweet rum, tart lemon, and soft touch of smoked wood. Incredible balance of sweet, smoky, and tart. Each sip is a different balance on those three. Never obnoxious but always intense. Fucking A this is awesome!

Bottle 12fl.oz. @ Halloween Tasting by cgarvieuk.Unclear medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, candy, bubble gum, cranberry syrup. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, candy, artificial, cranberry syrup. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20101030]
Golden red pour with little head.  Smells of tart cherries.  A very good mix of sweet and tart as the fruit seems to mix with the oak.  Yet another world class fruit beer from Dan and Deb.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a slightly cloudy caramel  color with a small off white head.  Aroma of cinnamon and apple spice.  Taste of cinnamon, apples and sour cranberries.  Cranberries come out as this warms.

She rests in my glass painted in the softest of rose petals. Soft whites line her outer edges while a touch of lace lingers. Her nose is cranberries and cream with a very soft pie-like crust accent. A pause then I am right back in the midst of cranberries and cream, freshly picked and freshly whipped respectively speaking. Not overly tart, though by nature the cranberries are a tart tickle mixed in with the creamy softness of her nose. My first quaff is a generous mouthful and if I close my eyes, I can very easily taste the fresh homemade cranberry pie, crust still warm, as it enters my mouth and makes sweet love to my tastebuds. Delish! Subtle cranberry tartness tickles my tongue while all around smooth layers of cranberry, cream, and doughy pie crust whisper sweet nothings in my ear. Complexity may not be the name of her game but what she lacks in that department she more than makes up for in the luxuriousness of her palate. Creamy, smooth, and with the mouthfeel of frothed milk, she floats over, across, and down my throat to leave but a lacey memory in my glass. Darn, that was good.


Does a beer have to be extremely complex to be good? Absolutely not. She just needs flavor and a good heart.

Bottle. Pours bit hazy deep golden with a medium off white head. The aroma is sweet fruit and sweet berries with some dry light acidic touch. Light honey notes. The flavour is light acidic, sweet caramel, sweet berries and fruit. Some oak and wood. Long fruity finish. Very nice!

Bottle kindly shared by plovmand, thanks krop, very appreciated! ;-) 
Pours hazy amber with a white head. 
Aroma is sweet syrup, malt and oak with dry fruity hints. 
Flavour is nice and dry, not as sweet as the aroma, probably due to the bitter cranberries. Its a little thin bodied, but with a nice oakyness balancing the malt and fruit.

Bottled, halloween tasting @ cgarvieuk. Hazy dark golden colour, white head. Aroma is fruit, cranberry, bubble gum, candy. Flavour is light malted, sour fruity, cranberry, bit of bubble gum. Sweet finish.

Bottle at Craigs big Edinburgh tasting, this bottle courtesy of Craig, thanks mate. Shared in company of Craig, Stella, Jan, Charlotte, Fritz and Loz 30.10.10   Pours amber with a white head. Nice streaky fruitiness dashing through straight away, fizzy but soft fizzy in the mouth. Really tart but balanced with sweetness. This is a zappy mouth awakener that said its also balanced by a hefty sweetness. Aroma is more shyer than expected.   A7 A4 T8 P4 Ov15   3.8
bottle at halloweeen tasting ... copper ... thin white lacing... big cranberry nose ... sweet wsweet artificial cranberry ... little cremola foam ... ok. not really me

Bottle [12oz] shared with HogTownHarry & garthicus -- c/o HogTownHarry. Pours a clear orange-amber with a small semi-lasting frothy off-white head. Aroma is sweet and lightly sour with raspberries, cranberries, some vinous notes, wood and even some light barnyard funk -- lots going on and it smells great. Flavour is fruity, sweet and lightly funky with lots of cranberries and sweet malt. Medium bodied. Fantastic stuff, a pleasure to drink.

From dkachur @ 12th Richmond Gathering. Aroma is quite similar to that of a sour ale. Taste is a lot sweeter, like artificial sweetner in candies. The taste is actually almost balanced out by the cranberries from becoming too sweet, though the belgian candi sugar tends to overpower the aftertaste quite a bit in the end.

12oz bottle shared with blankboy and garthicus, via trade with JCapriotti - thanks, J!!  Slightly hazy coppery gold with a smallish frothy off-white head (3+).  Smells ... lovely;  dry oak, vaguely of strawberry jam and plenty of lemon, yeast and slightly green berryfruit.  Taste follows, even more musty oak, somewhat tarter, hardly any alcohol, and again, I get that strawberry/rhubarb jam thing ... mmmm!  Chewy, moderately carbonated, mildly acidic, nice dry tingly finish - totally sessionable "sour" beer, could drink a pitcher of this!

Thanks to HogTownHarry! Appearance: lightly brown, small white head. Aroma: slightly acidic, an ice cider type nose, bitter with a good dose of cranberry in there too. Flavour: deliciously acidic, not so much tart but sharp, lovely cranberry and blueberry, sharp short bitter sweet finish. Delicious.

Thanks to, "hannont" for this beaut! Colour... orange-amber with no head. Nose... musty and fruity! Palate... burst of cranberry to start the festivities then lightly tart, slightly musty and quite spritely across the palate.

Thanks to Justin for sending this my way
I poured this brew in to a flute and it produced a short lived white fizzy head sitting on top of a cranberry colored body.

Growing up in the northeast and picking wild cranberries for years It was hard to mistake the aroma or the flavor of fresh cranberries in this brew. The body was very effervescent you just have to use that word for this one it fits it so well. The flavors were drying and tart,it just kept you coming back for more. Another great brew in the unplugged series, I cant wait to try more.

Serving type: bottle

On the bus at RBSG 10. Pours a reddish amber with a pinkish head. Nose is cranberry juice and tartness. Not particularly funky. A bit musty and sherry like. Light vinegar. On taste, it is tart, though hard to say if it is bacterial or from the cranberry. There is a light oak note that counters the acidity. A bit sweeter than expected. Overall, pretty good and a nice change of pace.

There is a wild lambic and cranberry tart aroma. The appearance iis pin k amber with a small head. The flavor of cran almost sprite from the tartness of the cranberries. It is very refreshing and flavorful, a delicious lambic.

12oz bottle courtesy of maximum12. thanks, corey! pours a clear, light, reddish copper with a thin, bubbly, white head and light lacing. aroma is great with sweet, candied cranberries, oak, vanilla, and hints of raspberry preserves with just the lightest touch of funk and tart, red wine vinegar. flavor is wonderful as well, a bit more tart than the aroma lets on, with crisp cranberry, blackberry, raspberry, and lemon pulp up front backed by sweet vanilla, bready yeast, and light, grassy funk with a dry, sweet finish. palate is medium bodied with strong carbonation and a very nice balance of sweet and tart flavors. overall, a damn nice brew.
From dkachur @ 12th Richmond Gathering: Wood, old, sour nose, fairly typical of the New Glarus Unplugged series. Clear amber, thin head. Cranberry flavor, pleasantly tart. Solidly good.

(Sample Date: 9/18/2010   Source:Dkachur)   Woody with a light fruitiness. Smells wonderful Clear light reddish copper with small white head. Sour and tangy with a good bit of wood. Nice complexity. Light body with a light fizzy mouth feel. Finish is woody sour and acidic.

Sampled at the Richmond Gathering XII.  Thanks dkachur!  Bright clear amber pour with very minimal white head ring.  Smells like if kellog made a cranberry poptart.  Flavor is pastry, acidic, tart, very sweet (like sugar).  Very good.

Bottle courtesy of dkachur at the 12th Richmond Ratebeer Gathering on 09/18/2010. Clear copper amber body with a small frothy white head. Big oak, vanilla and cranberry aroma. Tart cranberry flavor with lots of oak and vanilla. Medium light body with moderately high carbonation.

bottle poured an orange amber in color with a ring of white head. aroma has cranberry, mild acidity, some yeast, and a bit of funk. mouth feel is light and there is little carbonation. flavor has funky cranberry, medium acidity, some barrel wood, vanilla, malts, and earthy yeast. definitely interesting with the typical ng. fruits mixed in with the barrels and funk.

12oz bottle.

Pours a clear pinkish amber with a bubbly off-white, slightly pink head that recedes to a rocky collar and spotty lacing.

The aroma is very sweet with brown sugar, tart cranberries and a bit of funk.  There is also an oaky character to the nose but its mostly sweetness.

The taste is all about the cranberries, super sweet and sugary with a pleasant tartness in the finish.  Sticky sweet finish with a little oak though the wood is very subtle.

The mouthfeel is medium bodied with good carbonation and definitely on the sweeter side as lambics are concerned.

As usual, New Glarus hits a home run with a fruit beer.  Like an amped up Raspberry Tart with a bit of funk and oak.  Crazy drinkable.

12oz bottle thanks to mikesgroove.
Appearance : Clear amber with no head. Not much lacing.

Aroma : Intense fruits with hints of bubblegum. Cough syrup. 

Taste : Intense fruits, slightly tart and quite sweet. Notes of cinnamon and vanilla. Finish is very fruity with notes of vanilla and something close to cinnamon. 

Overall : Very intense beer. Inferior to the Belgian Red and Raspberry Tart to me. Nice furits but a bit too syrupy. Not sure if I could have this 12oz bottle by myself. Glad I tried it but I will not seek this again.

Bottle. Clear copper pour, a bit of white foamy head. Aroma is quite woody, vanilla, butter, herbs, sour dough, ketchup, fruit and generally a bit too strong. Taste is much better, quite mellow, lightly sour, you can taste the cranberry acidity more than you can actually smell them, light fruity sweetness makes everything all the more enjoyable. Palate is lightly carbonated and ok.

GABF 2009 backlog. Pours orange amber with a retentive Ivory head. Great berry and wild funky aroma. Lighter side of medium bodied with a great mouthfeel, somewhat refreshing. Flavor of cranberries and malt, but with balanced sour and acetic qualities of the wild yeast. Slight oakiness and acidity on the finish. Great stuff

12 ounce bottle courtesy of CaptainCougar, thank you sir.  Pours bright and clear blood orange, tiny edge bubbles, moderate lacing.  Aroma of apple skins, cranberries, lemon, white grapes.  Taste has a slightly sweet start then transitions to moderate acidity.  Halfway through, a bit of funk shows up and stay through the finish, which also ends on sour summer fruit notes.  Interesting and unique.

12 oz. bottle; pours glowing mix of light orange and copper with trace white head along the edges; spur cherries, buttery bread, apple skins; light texture with silky cherries and very faint tart cranberries; mix of light whet and cranberry juice; not overly rich like some other NG fruit beers; dry fruit, light wheat; pretty tasty and very easy to drink, but doesnt quite do it for me; nose has some slight butter to me; cranberries and light caramel

My Bottom Line:
Bubblegum phenols and cranberry juice aplenty move into pleasant sourness, as mineral qualities peer through once in a while.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A veil of foam tops the clear amber.
-The nose is rather powerful, reminiscent of cake icing and fruit candy.
-Mild wheat biscuits are found underneath.
-The overtly juicy character makes this quenching.

Bottle.

Bottle.
Taste and aroma of wild strawberries, raspberries and cranberries. 
Good body and a balanced sweetness. But still, to me this is alco pop rather than a beer just like the other New Glarus fruit beers Ive tried

Bottle. Pours red-orange. No head. The aroma is an explosion of sweet, sweet fruit and berries. Only New Glarus can come up with this stuff! Notes of cloudberries and raspberries (even if its brewed with cranberries...). The taste is as sweet and fruity as the aroma, but a bit one dimensional in the long run. Slightly vinous. Not the most compex beer. Sticky textture. Medium bodied.

This poured a ruby red color with a smaller pinkish beige head. Aroma was of lots of tart cranberries, some slight funk and yeast. Flavor was a great mixture of the sourness from the cranberries as well as the wild yeast, and just enough toasted malt backbone to keep it balanced. Great stuff.

In short: An intense sweet, tart, acidic and spicy fruity beer like no other.  Excellent
How: Bottle 12oz.  Consumed a little over 6 months after it was bottled.  Bottle sent to me by oakbluff, thanks a lot Scott.
The look: Clear dark golden body topped by a small white head
In long: Intense nose blending maraschino cherries, fresh berries and a spiciness reminding me of those they use in Halloween pumpkin beers.  Taste is very fruity and very juicy.  I noted a bunch of red juicy fruits (cherries, raspberries, wild berries, strawberries, litchis, cranberries) as well as a lot of kiwis and some vanilla.  The beer is a bit sweet with a sweetness that feels like white-sugar.  Strong nutmeg and cinnamon spiciness.  Finish is very tart and sharp and that totally washes the sweetness and spiciness away.  Medium acidity from start to finish.  Carbonation is very active, almost aggressive.  This is an intense beer, almost a sipper.  It is also a very original one, I cannot really think of another beer even remotely similar to this one.  Kick-ass stuff.  God, I love to drink beer.  And no, I dont have a problem with alcohol.  I only get shivers, shakes and seizures without it.

Glowing orange rusty color/ beige foam. Big tart cherry-cranberry, lemon, saw dust, cinnamon spice aromas.  Light bodied with soft co2. Biting tannic cranberry tart flavor at first turns to sugary sweet,  with dry wood, spicy cinnamon, and a drying finish. Nice mesh of sweet, tart, and spice here. Thanks again Jason for this bottle.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text:
UPDATED: MAR 4, 2012 dakine with the last bottle of the night on 3/8/10.

clear. orange pinkish amber colored pour with a white head.

neat aroma... lemon tartness, cranberry, savory wood, vanilla, dust and florals with a little spice tingle. 

the flavor is the same... cranberry comes through mildly. tannic dryness on the finish breaks up an otherwise fairly sweet beer. 

medium bodied and a bit stickier than i was expecting. still, i could drink a lot of this. 8/4/8/3/16/3.9
3/4/12
Much more tart....,wet grain,wood,bile,vanilla,fruity. Quite nice.4

20100725  12oz bottle from the brewery.  Pours the color of a Shirley Temple with a quick, fizzy, soda-like pale pink head.  The aroma is nice, full of cranberry, some lemony hints, yogurt, and a fairly hefty dose of oak, honey, graham.  Fuller bodied than Id have expected or desired, and kind of sweet for something cranberry or lambic, let alone a cran-bic.  By mid palate the beer awakens with a beautiful acidity of both fruit and wild beer, and it lingers with a further woody acidity culminating with a nearly sour brown character except for some sweet honey and floral/herb (oregano).  I had this another time, maybe at Pilsner Peters last event, and didnt like it nearly as much as I do now.
12 oz.  Great beer,   strong hits of vanilla and oak.   reddish color, sweet but not to sweet.  i will seek out more

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2010 Shared at a recent little tasting. This was absolutely, with out a doubt, one outstanding beer. The aromas were fruity and very easy on the nose. The flavors held a tart sweet bitter taste to it that left me begging for more. Hopefully I can try this one again.

Bottle, thanks to GuyinChicago for the share. Pours clar pinkish-amber, thin head, no lacing. Nose is cranberries, Danish butter-cookies; tart and berryish flavour, crabapple jelly, tart finish. Tasty.
Shared at a Tampa crew tasting 7-22-2010. Caramel, oak, alcohol, light cranberry.  mild sourness, medium sweetness, light stickiness. Interesting and enjoyed.

Bottle from Hoppymeal, thanks! Cranberries in the aroma. Sour flavor with red berries, cranberries and lemon. Soft bitter notes from the cranberries. Longish sharp citrus aftertaste. Hints of oak and vanilla. Quite likeable.

Poured a pinkish hue with a little head.  Traditionally fruit beers have not been my thing.  But this was surprisingly good.  The nose is huge cranberry.  The taste was smooth and sweet with tons of cranberry and a little vanilla on the back burner.

Orange amber pour with a small white head. The aroma is huge diacetyl at first with sugary cranberry notes as well. The flavor is buttery cranberry with dried acidic cranberry sauce notes. I really cant get past the butter. The palate is smooth, effervescent, and finishes just like a bite of dried cranberry.

Rusty orange pour with a small, short-lived, white head.  Lots of fresh, tart cranberry aroma with some subtle toffee and honey sweetness.  Some subtle funk and sour in the back ground with hints of oak and spice.  Huge lactic sour and tart cranberry bite in the flavor.  This is some serious sour!  The oak blends very nicely with the light malt sweetness.  The oak character is very light.  White oak barrels maybe?  Theres some grainy wheat in the malt profile and it finishes a little vinous with some white grape and mixed fruit notes.  The body is light, crisp and very dry with loads of carbonation.
Pours copper with a minimal head.  Big aroma of berry, malt, and a little sour.  Big sour tart flavor, wood, some berry, sweet malt, and syrupy.  Tasty!

12 oz bottle from nimbleprop. Nose is cranberries, woody oak, and very light funkiness. Cranberry gold with a small off white head. Flavor is  cranberries, malty sweetness, and a tiny bit of bitter. Too sweet IMHO!

The cranberry aroma is great but it is really hard to pick any oakiness out of it. The taste is nice and tart when it initially hits your tongue. Then the great smokey oak barrel notes. Another great fruit beer that you would expect from New Glarus.

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2010 Pink_red like pour that is clear as a bell.  Thin galaxy shaped head in my glass.  Musty, semi-stinky barn aromas with a cloying sweetness.  The flavor is better. Lightly tart at the start followed by a fruity sweet flavor that has some cranberry influence. Reminds me of the grape juice we used to get on Put-n-bay on lake Erie when I was young. Sparkling mouthfeel with light body. Thanks for the bottle, Matt.

Pours a dark red/pink/brown with an off-white head.  Aroma is tart dark fruit, cranberry, funk.  Flavor is tart, crisp, yet sweet and full.  Really nice balance.  Good sour puckering notes with a good fruit flavor.  A bit one note, but its a good note.  Maybe a touch sweet on the backend  Good beer.

12oz bottle thanks to Ughsmash 
Appearance: Pours slightly hazy amber with a nice off-white head that dissipates quickly, lots of bubbles coming up from the bottom of the glass. A light reddish tint to the body and head 
Aroma: Crisp aroma! Slightly tart fruits, oak and vanilla 
Taste: Tart fruits (cranberries), vanilla, woody with a dry finish 
Very nice!
Bottle thanks to MrPickles.  Orange-red, off white cover.  Aroma is tart cranberries, sweet.  Taste is very nice tart, some vinegar, acetic, cranberry lingers.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2010 6/18/10.  Aroma of oak, cranberry.  Sweet taste with a strong cranberry presence.  Slight tart.  Rounded oak in the finish.  Unique beer but a tad too sweet for my personal tastes.  Glad I tried it nonetheless.

7/22/10.  2nd bottle.  Picking up a bit more tart (almost mild sour) in the finish and the beer seems a touch less sweet than the bottle a month prior. +.1 for Palate as the tart cleans up the sweet.

A solid pour into my large Tripel Karmeliet tulip produces a two-finger thick, pale tan colored head.  The beer is a brilliantly clear, red color with gold around the edges.  As I pour this notes of tart cranberry aromatics are noticeable; a more focused inspection of the nose yields a more concentrated version of the same, but also noticeable is a musty, spicy, woody oak notes as well as some buttery oak character, toasted wood notes and even some vanillin aromatics.  Of the base beer not much of anything is noticeable, but the oak does a good job of balancing the cranberry notes; at least in the nose.

This is sweet tasting, though not as aggressively as the Wisconsin Belgian Red.  The cranberries contribute a tartness as well as a general fruitiness, but arent actually all that noticeable as a characteristic cranberry flavor; actually now that I think about it the fruitiness in the nose is pretty non-descript as well.  Some acetic-like acidity adds a piquancy to this beer, which helps to mitigate the sweetness just a bit.  The oak is a bit more subtle than it was in the nose, but is definitely a big part of the flavor profile; a subtle spicy oak character, some raw woody notes, and some buttery oak flavors are joined by a hint of vanillin.  There is a certain tannic astringency to this beer that makes me think of cranberries, but is more likely contributed by the oak character.  The flavors remind me of apple juice, or perhaps cran-apple juice.  The residual sugars contribute to a medium fullness to the body.

Not a bad beer, I like that it is not too aggressively sweet tasting, but it certainly doesnt have a characteristic flavor or aroma of cranberries; if I hadnt already known about the cranberries I likely would have guessed that another fruit, or even none at all was used in this beer.  This was about what I expected, but man what I wouldnt give for New Glarus to produce a traditional, funky, fruited sour beer.  The heavy filtering that this beer has seen definitely has had an effect on the flavor of this beer.  This isnt remotely close to a traditional Lambic though does compare well if compared with the Lindemans of the world.

Bottle thanks to Randy. Pours a nice reddish amber with creamy white head. Nose is cranberries and cough medicine. Taste is wonderful cranberries, cream and a gingerbread finish. Great tasting beer. A 4.0+ beer if not for the nose.

Bottle from SkyView. Pours a dark copperish color with a small off white head that recedes to a small ring. Nose is tart, but candy like with a nice honey and bready malt scent. Smell is very sweet and tart at the same time. Palate is firm and has a very big carbonation rush up front with a sweet and almost sour finish that lasts on the tongue and roof of the mouth. Flavor is bready malts with sour, lactic, tart, sweet, honey, toast, fruit notes. This is a nice brew.

Pours a red tinted darkish amber with a 2 finger creamy white head that has excellent retention. Aroma is oak with little to no toast, funky wet leaves, great tart and sweet cranberry notes, basement, dusty tree fruit and a touch of sweet grain. Flavor is sweet and tart cranberry, lots of earthy, wet forest funk, definitebut light oak notes, sour citrus, basement, a touch of grass and light toasty grain. Some more oak and a little vanilla come out as it warms, but otherwise it remains quite bright and funky. Palate is light to medium bodied with a slightly sticky entry dry though not drying finish and moderate strength, apropriately kinda sharp carbonation. Ridiculously good brew, definitely have to save a few of these back for Thanksgiving dinner.

Nice tart and woody nose, earthy notes of cranberry, a little sweetness, but nice tart and fruity. A touch funky and interesting on the nose as well. Pours reddish with little head. The flavor is full of cranberries, wood, lightly funky, earth. Solid and tart, a real showcase for the cranberry flavors. Solidly carbonated, dry and bright. Would like more please!

Thanks to lufootball for the bottle.  Pours a still and clear golden bronze.  Aroma of tart fruits.  Flavors almost remind me more of an apple cider than cranberry lambic, but the tart cranberry flavor is powerful in the finish and lingers for a while.  Easy to drink and very tasty.

This is one of my first forays into fruit beers although I have had some lambics before. I poured from a bottle into a tulip glass. Poured a beautiful light crimson color with a small head. Smells of tart fruit and maybe sherry like alcohol notes. Taste does not dissappoint, nice tart sour flavors of cran followed by a subtle sweetness to finish it off. Has an excellent light feel in the mouth. Very smooth from start to finish. 
I am really impressed with this. Not something I could drink everyday as it was a little sweet but very tasty. I need to go buy more!

Appearance: Pours a transparent brown with light garnet tinge. Head is slightly off white and minimal, as is the retention. Some lace.

Smell: Good mixture of cranberries, leather, cobwebs, oak, and lactic tartness.

Taste: Good amount of tartness followed by a semi sharp cranberry acidity. earthy grain, and wheat. Well done!

Mouthfeel: Crisp, fairly light, carbonation seems correct.

Drinkability: Very drinkable for a fruit lambic.

Another home run! Dan Carey is a genius with a better batting average than most brewers!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-01-2009

The Dan Journal #349.  Tasted 5/13/10.  12oz bottle.  Pours lively and filtered with a reddish hue.  Spiraling white head.  Aromas of tart vinegar, citrus, woody oaky and earthy.  Wow, what a big nose!  It keeps me sniffing!  Medium bodied with a great palate.  Nice mix of tart, bitter, vinegary fruit juxtapositioned with a big woody, oaky vanilla  flavor.  The cranberry is noticeable yet well blended.  Tart and tangy with a mellow finish.  Lingering bitter fruit and a cloying mouthfeel.  This is really good!  But then, its a fruit beer from New Glarus!  No surprise there.

Bottle:  Pours a bright, yet dark golden pour with a large, frothy white head.  Aroma is sweet and fruity.  Initially smells a little like apple juice before the tartness of the cranberries comes forward.  The cranberry presence in the taste is sublime.  Very nice balance of sweet to tart.  Not really tasting the oak, but I can sense its presence.  Light bits of vanilla.  Finished dry.  Quite nice.
thanks to Hophead22 for the tasting.From a 12oz bottle,sour cranberry flavor,light pink in color,smells of  a sour beer and cranberries.

12oz bottle provided by Kevin. Rating #177. Crystal clear orange pour with a white head. Light fruit aroma, a tiny bit tart. Light sweetness and a bit tart, nice little cranberry flavor too it, real nice. (1226)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: "Big thanks to Louis for this unexpected treat. Ruby copper colored body with a foam around the outer edge and very minimal lacing. Sweet, tart cranberries are abundant within the aroma. Dry and refreshing, mildly tart with a mellowing sweetness. Cranberry, wheat and more cranberry."

Bottle courtesy of Nelson Davila, Couriered to Boston, flown to Puerto Rico. Clear redish amber with tall off- white head. Sweet fruit and spice aroma. Fruity, slightly tart flavour, wild yeasts seem tame, no overly funky notes here. Notes of vanilla and oak.  Quite enjoyable lambic style brew

12oz bottle 5/6/10 (Courtesy of FlandersNed)-42° in Flute. Pours a lighter amber with a small white ring for a head. Aroma of cranberries, yeast, and oak. Taste of oak, cranberries, tart, and funkiness. This light bodied brew is different but still very enjoyable. Nice job.

Bottle from StFun, thanks dude!  Poured a reddish-amber color with a thin, bubbly pink-tinged head that faded to a ring.  Aroma of lightly tart cranberries, lightly funky yeast, oak, and some soft vanilla.  Smooth, lightly sweet entry transitions into a moderately tart, funky yeastiness with some light cobweb that is paired with a soft cranberry fruitiness and soft, dry undertones of oak and a light vanilla sweetness.  Low carbonation and smooth, dry palate.  Overall, the taste delivered a more rounded and enjoyable version of the sweet, fruity nose.  Luckily there was enough dryness to offset the sweetness and create an enjoyable beer.  Thanks again Josh.

From a trade with MoeJuck, thanks! Awesome beer for those of us who love cranberries and tart funkiness. Pours a rose color, aroma mostly cranberry, slight sour funk.  Flavor is wonderfully full of cranberry goodness, and the tart that comes with it, as well as a mild funkiness, and a slight graininess on the finish. Crazy drinkable, wish I had a case of them. Excellent!

[Bottle] Pours amber-red with a small white head that fades to nearly nothing. Aroma is, surprise, big on cranberry. There is also some funkiness and tartness, combined with raspberry, and some sweeter scents that I cannot describe. Taste is cranberry, some vanilla, almost some very faint notes of cinnamon at times, oak, lots of tannins, and a light funkiness. Excellent. Medium-thin mouthfeel, and long finish. Im a sucker for cranberry beers, and this one is particularly well done. Insanely drinkable, and one that I forsee craving in the future.
Reddish pour with a red-tinted white head. Aroma is predominately cranberries with a whiff of some yeast. Taste is tart cranberries, quite nice and rich, with some wood and vanilla in there. Yeah!

12 oz. bottle via trade - Pours a clear reddish-brown color with a nice size off white head.  Faint lacing.  Aroma is very nice.  Lots of berry esters and aromas I cant nail down.  Flavor is slightly tart fruit.  Again, there is a lot more to the flavor I cant describe.  Lightly carbonated and medium body.  Honestly, I dont care about describing this beer, its just a pleasure to drink.  Thanks to whomever sent this to me.

12 oz bottle poured into my flute glass.

A-Body is a transparent rose hue. Pours with a minimal 1 finger or so soapy white head-but this fades quickly to a thin collar. Very few traces of lacing are left in the glass. A steady, mild stream of tiny bubbles rises to the top.

S-The nose is mostly, if not all, dry fruity cranberries. Nose reminds me of Arbor Mist wine.

T- Flavor is mild upfront and offers sweet, dry cranberry. A mild amount of tartness comes through for the finish-which is relatively dry. Theres not much more to the flavor profile its all mild to moderate cranberry.

P-Medium spritzy carbonation and light, dry body.

O-This is a decent-pretty good lambic overall. Its certainly better than SA cranberry lambic. The overall profile is pretty mild and it has a lot of wine-like qualities. There are better lambics out there-but this one is definitely worth a try.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-26-2010 05:07:58

Impressive stuff here. Nicely carbonated, great cranberry aroma, mixed with some oak and citric tartness. Its an almost perfect blend of sweet and sour, with sweet fruity notes mixing perfectly with the lemony tartness. A little bit of  oaky notes, too. Really good...

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2016 Pours a glimmering Ruby red  body with a pink head that doesnt have a. Long retention . Nose is a explosion of fresh cranberries, strawberries, sour apples and wood. Lively carbonation. Taste is sweet,cranberries, oak, and floral hops, with a long sour finish. Nice beer. Honestly this is a different recipe from the last iteration of the cranbic.

Received via a trade, drank in a New Glarus Flute Glass (also via this trade).  The aroma is sweet on the nose with hints of cranberry, lemon, and a slight floral hint.  The beers is orangy amber in appearance with little to no head, but leave a slight resin on the side of the glass as it is consumed. Taste is a little sour, with a strong cranberry taste. It is a little bubbly on the palate very lively and a little bitter.  Overall this is exactly what I expected, a good one off by a great brewery.

Pours deep clear red with white head, aroma is nice cranberry, vanilla, oak and some funk.  Taste up front is sweet cranberries and a hint of sweeter berries with some funk, leading into oak and a nice tart and dry finish.  Pretty good, wish this was a bit more sour!

Bottle from Matt (madvike). Translucent pinkish-orange body, thin off-white head. Tart nose with cranberry, sugar, vinaigrette, and sour funk. The body reminds me a lot of the Raspberry Tart and Belgian Red, tart yet not quite puckering, mildly sweet with a firm, biting grassy bitterness in the finish and the tannic, fleeting nature of delicious ripe cranberries. Dry oaky notes complement the fruit and funk. Very good; this would have been suited for the larger bottle treatment its cherry and raspberry East Egg cousins receive.

Pours to a bright orange brassy body with a quickly dissipating fizzy white head.  Rapid carbonation is visible from many feet away.  The aroma is sour and full of cranberry with sour mash and a light hay.  The flavor is tart and tangy with cranberry, slightly sweet on the finish, some sweet oat.  Id say that if General Mills made a Cranberry Cheerios, that this is what it would taste like.  Perhaps not the sharp sourness up front, but that hearty grain packed cranberry mixture on the finish.  The palate is very sour up front but has a sweeter lingering back end.

Bottle thanks to pantanap. Bright red and clear. Nose is lambic-ky and tart. Taste starts off sweet and the sour and bitterness kicks in. Fruity, dry but not as tart as the nose would suggest. Very carbonated and fluffy. Interesting but not life changing.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Thanks to Exiled for sharing this bottle. The beer pours a clear, light amber color with a white head. The aroma is strong cranberry which not much else coming through. The flavor is a little more complex, but still heavy on the fruit. The beginning is sweet cranberrys and that is followed with some tart cranberry and oak characters. The beer is slightly puckering but is not as sour as some other beers. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A very nice American lambic that really showcases cranberries while not tasting like a wine cooler or some of the lower rated fruit lambics that you see on the shelves.

12 oz. bottle from the brewery.  Pours a clear reddish amber color with a tiny beige head that leaves little trace.  Aroma of berries and other fruits- cranberry, cherry, grape, apple- and vanilla, with notes of minerals, butter, and wood.  Flavor of tart, juicy cranberries, cherries, apples, grapes, acidic notes, wild yeast, vanilla, and metallic and mineral notes.  Light-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a juicy mouthfeel.  A really cool, unusual fruit beer.  New Glarus seems to be the best at these.

Bottle split by iowaherkeye - thanks Joey!  Pours a nice darker-pink with minimal white head.  Nose is very big berry which is sort of like a pickled raspberry.  Also grass, candi sugar, and acid.  Flavor does have the round fruitiness of Enigma - that sort of tart red juiciness - but ultimately this ends with much more peel and less pulp than that beer does, which makes sense given the fruit choice.  The tartness is mostly subsumed, but outlasts the fruit by a hair.  Light pickle also in the finish.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2010 
Name: Unplugged Cran-Bic Ale
Date: February 12, 2010
Mode: Bottle
Source: Trade
Appearance: clear red, scant head, sudsy lace
Aroma: musty aroma, touch of sweet fruity character, light tartness
Body: creamy body
Overall: sweet cranberry aroma, light tartness, touch of mustyness that should develop nicely over the next couple of years
Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3.3/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: **+ /4
Hazy golden-red pour with a small vanishing head.  Awesome sour cranberries with a bit of grain and yeast.  Slightly sweet and sour at the same time.  Delicious stuff!

Bottle poured clear red, with a tiny vanishing white head.  Aroma of tart fruit, vanilla oak notes.  Taste is clearly cranberry, with oak notes, and nice earthy fruity finish.  Mouth is lightly carbonated and dry.  Overall, a nice fruity brew.  Very nice blance between the tart fruit and oak.

Bottle. Nose is sweet cranberry and musk. Clear with yellow and pink at different thicknesses, effervescent. Sweet and sour define the flavor, but with depth and balance that is unbelievable. The inherent tartness of the fruit provides most of the sourness which gives it a very pleasant and natural feel. Palate is medium-thin but good carbonation gives a nice impression, finish is bone dry. Amazingly drinkable.

Bottle: pours hazy reddish with a thin white head, aroma of cranberry, candied sugar, taste is tart, fruity, light mouthfeel, my wife said the smell is the same as her bourbon cranberry sauce.  This is a little sweet for me but glad I got to try it.

Bottle thanks to Justin.  Pours a peachy amber.  Cranberry nose with some definite funky basement notes.  The taste is predominately sweet with a pronounced sourness.  Good bitter cranberry finish.  Despite the sweetness it is very dry, which I like quite a bit in the context.  Not bad at all.

12oz. bottle.  A crystal clear, dark pinkish-crimson colored body is crowned with a tall, decently retained head of ivory-beige froth.  After slowly settling to a thin film with a pronounced, bubbly edge, the head leaves skinny, diagonal flares and random spots of lacing behind.  The aroma features ultra-juicy, sweet-tart red berry notes, including the full lineup from cranberries and strawberries to rich cherry.  Vanilla is prominent, just like it is in Belgian Red.  Somehow, it refrains from seeming medicinal, a flaw that probably 90% of fruit beers are prone to.  The flavor follows suit, exploding with juicy cherry-berry notes, showing mostly sweet but with a slightly wild, tart yeast-twang on the back end.  Vanilla is the other major component, though its more of the sweet bean variety than the woody oak type.  On the palate, the body gets some welcomed heft from the residual sugar, while fine, lively carbonation distributes the fruity tartness evenly.  This is most certainly nothing like a true lambic, but throwing stylistic guidelines out the window, its a damn delicious beer.  Cran-bic is further proof that Daniel Carey it the master of the non-lambic fruit beer, amongst other styles.
This made me remember why I like beer so much. The amber color, the  friuty fresh smell, the impeccable flavor. I hope they promote this to a full time beer. It is fantastic.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours golden orange with a fully gone head. Aroma is dry acidic and light butterish. Sweet and fruity, light sticky texture. Mild acidic note. Lingering fruity with a light fruity note. Smooth fruity and medium dry into the far finish.

Bottle thanks to jcb!Transparent red with a small off-white head. Lightly tart nose of lactic cranberry with some wood and faint spice tossed in. Rich, sweet cranberry flavor, some grass and lactic sourness providing and odd combination. Stinging carbonation accompanies the thin body and short cranberry and fruit-skin finish. Its nice, but this isnt Raspberry Tart, and the sweetness here sticks in the finish, making even the thin body seem syrupy.

Ruby pour with a low offwhite head.  Aroma is bursting with juicy cranberries, some low tartness.  Flavor is mostly cranberry, very juicy and fresh, tart in its own respect, but added around the middle is a rustic yeast tartness as well that works very well, finishes slightly dry.  Very unique.
Tried at Woodshop 5.0.  Amber color.  Wow, that is really good.  Sour and fruity.  Excellent.

A: The pour is an amazingly clear ruby color with a lot of carbonation bubbles, but just about no head.

S: The smell is interesting. There is a mild tartness, cranberry, and also a sweet aroma. A slight bit of spice is also in the background.

T: This one is really full of cranberry, as you might expect. There is a mild tartness, but definitely not up to par with what you might think of when you hear a bear labeled as a *-bic. The sweetness is mild at first, but becomes more pronounced throughout the drinking experience.

M: There is a very nice, crisp feeling on the tongue, with plentiful carbonation.

D: The beer is fairly drinkable, but becomes just too sweet as you get through the glass.

Another interesting beer from New Glarus, but a bit more of a sugary beer than I was expecting. Its definitely not a lambic, but its still significantly better than Sam Adams offering.

(Draught and a bottle, courtesy thirdeye11)  Pours a clear pinkish-red body with small off-white head.  Aroma of nuts, caramel, lemon, light horse blanket, and cranberries.  Flavor of cranberry juice, lemon, and some brett with a dry finish.

Thanks to rgtravers for this one! Ive had a craving to try this beer for a while now. It pours a pink color with a small white head. The aroma is funky with a lovely berry character. The flavor is syrupy with tart cranberries, cherry syrup, and fermentables. This is a perfect beer for food pairings. More interesting and complex with the varied berry flavor and funkyness than most fruit beers.

[Bottle] Pours a brown/ruby color with a quickly receding white head. Aroma of cranberry, light oak and vanilla. Taste includes lots of tart cranberry, some cinnamon and nutmeg. Didnt get much funk in here. Seemed pretty clean and straight-forward to me; like a cranberry version of their other popular fruit beers. Lingering cran-raspberry flavored sweetness in the finish. Prickly carbonation really hits the back of your throat. Another solid fruit beer from New Glarus!

12oz bottle.  Pours a clear red/pinkish dark golden with tight pink tinted compact head that leaves some spotty lacing.  Tons of juicy cranberry, almost syrupy, with some dry wood and light lacto tartness.  Not overly complex or super funky but it smells like there could be some sour in there.  A bit of tart metallic up front that quickly moves into lots of flavorful cranberry fruitiness that is almost equally sweet as it is tart.  The oak isnt very prevalent, but I suppose it dose add some dryness, a touch of chalk as well a hint of earthiness.  Another solid fruit beer from one of the best.  Thanks Tim and Jason both for hooking me up with a bottle.

Tap at GABF 09.  Pours a clear bright copper with a thin lasting head.  Aroma is mostly fruity upfront with sour cherry, light cranberry, mineral, pitty and earthy- sour hints, woody and grassy with some light plasticy notes.  Flavor is oaky vanilla, some cherry, more cranberry although light and fermented out quite a bit- some farmhouse funk, strange off- acids, barnyard light plastic, earth, cherry pits, tannic and more oak.  Not too bad, but not as great as I had hoped.

12 ounce bottle courtesy of thickfreakness. Pours a light orange-pink with a compact pinkinsh head. Aroma is of cream and berries, slight earthiness to. Flavor starts a little sweet, wine-coolerish, then the tart comes around rapidly after that and stomps out most of the sweetness. Creaminess comes again in the middle and finishes it out. Cranberry and strawberry flavors are apparent the whole time. The flavor is pretty cloying even though it is subdued by the tart and other flavors - it is right below the surface the whole time, loads of sugar seemingly. Light mouthfeel, lower-medium carbonation. Enjoyable. I couldnt have more than one but I still dig the one Im having. Overall, good to very good.

Pours crystal clear amber / orange with a small white head.  The aroma has vanilla, oak, light bourbon and a hint of cranberry.  Medium smooth body thats slick and has light gentle carbonation.  The flavor starts with more cranberry than the aroma lets on.  It is nice and tart that is light on the sweetness and has some oak, light spice and is very clean.  The finish has peppery spice, cranberry, sweet tarts and there is quite a bit of bite.  Great beer.

Bottle.  Pours a clear ruby tinged orange with a thin to medium sized white head.   Light sweet fruit, a touch of funk and brett, a bit of vanilla, slightly vinous.  Wow, sweeter than expected.  Tastes like ice cream.  Vanilla and cherry ice cream. Very sweet, a bit of tartness.  Little cranberry dryness almost balances the overwhelming sweetness, but not quite.  Still tasty though.

Heres an old one.  12 oz bottle enjoyed with my wife on Thanksgiving 09. Pours clear and ruddy with a small, but fizzy head. Aroma is strongly cranberry accentuated by the lovely spiciness found in all NGs fruit beers. Taste is beautifully tart with loads of cranberry and cinnamon. Sweet, but balanced by the acidity. Medium carbonation and eminently drinkable. A perfect treat for the holidays.

Aroma had cranberry with hints of sourness.  Upfront cranberry flavor, sweetness and tartness.  Medium body, tart/dry finish.  Yummy, cant drink too many due to tartness, probably gors well with vanilla or chocolate ice cream.

Pours a vibrant mixture of orange, red and red with a fluffy white head. Smells of cranberry juice and funk, with maybe a hint of cherry. The flavor is an awesome mixture of tart and sweet. This is quite the "lambic". Thanks Ughsmash
bottle, thanks to thirdeye11, orange color with cranberry oaky aroma, flavors of cranberry syrup, wildflowers, malt vinegar, nice finish

12 ounce bottle courtesy of madvike who was kind enough to send me four of these. Thanks Matt! Once of the most anticipated NG beers for me in a long, long time. Pours a clear pale red color with a thin white head. Fair head retention and lacing. Aroma of cranberries and cherries with notes of coconut and wood. Tart and sweet at the same time. Taste is cherries, cranberries, faint funky notes, oak, vanilla. A faint bit of sugary vinegar if that makes any sense. The funk here is there but its very mild. Good entry level lambic. Insanely drinkable. Good beer.

Huge thanks to canIHAVE.  Dark amber pour with a small white head.  Aroma up front was the cranberries and quite a bit of funk and what I was thinking was tartness.  Flavor was cranberries, cinnamon, oak, caramel, cherries, and chocolate.  Finishes sweet but with enough acidity to balance it out.  Very interesting twist on fruit beer meets sour ale.

Bottle: Poured a light reddish color ale with a large foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of tart notes with light sweet cranberry and acidic undertones is very enticing. Taste is a complex mix between some lightly sweet cranberry with some tart notes with a well balanced finish that includes green apple-like acidity and some light funky ester. Even though this beer present great complexity it is still very easily drinkable and very refreshing which I rated very highly. Body is about average with great carbonation. An excellent beer from a brewer that consistently amaze me.

Pours a thin tan head, decent retention with minimal lace. Clear amber red hued brew. Nicely tart nose, cranberries, cherries, woody spicey notes. Body is lightly medium with a nice effervescence, lightly tart and prickly. Nice berry cherry flavor, hint of cinnamon, wood and a light earthyness,sour apples, maybe a tad funky also. Sweet tart finish, fruity and juicey with a light mustiness. Interesting brew. Props to my friend motortoddhead for this one!

Bottle javier brought to the tasting, tahnks dude.  This was really good and all in all very tasty!  Pours copper with no head.  Nose is cranberrtastic.  Taste is sweet with lots of crantasticness, love it.

bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  poured copper with a fading white head.  aroma was apple, cranberry, and honey.  flavor was cranberry and honey.  body was medium with medium carbonation.  i wasnt impressed with this beer.

I remember having this at GABF this year and not being overly ecstatic...and here I am again, not overly into this beer.  Pours a rosey amber, thin head, nose was cranberry sweet with malty undertones and not much else.  Flavors are on the sweet side with the cranberry notes coming through fairly evident yet simple...I just find it a bit too sweet, too simple with not much complexity to ponder..but, its clean and its good for what its trying to be i suppose.

Thanks to FlandersNed for this great brew!!

It pours crystal clear with an amazing orange/pinky color. Great tart/sweet cranberry flavor, excellent on the palate, all in all, in my opinion, this is a great brew.

12oz bottle, thanks to 17thfloor! Pours red and slightly hazed with small white head around the rim. Nose is loaded with fresh cranberries, just like at thanksgiving dinner, brown sugar in the background. Flavor has tar cranberries, sweet cane and brown sugar, and plum with a mild earthy-funk finish. Spritzy carbonation, syrupy body. New glarus is clearly the king of fruit beers (as if we didnt know).

Chitown RB gathering Jan 2010: bottle shared by Vince (beernbourbon), many thanks!  Deep amber with some reddish highlights, light head and good lace. The aroma has notes of cranberry, flowery and barnyardy esters, some sugar, woody and earthy. The taste is too sweet for the lambic genre but fine for a fruit beer. Very fruity, grainy and a bit toasty. The mouth feel is medium-bodied, soft and touch chalky. Okay but then I was not honestly expecting much from this beer. Perhaps time will change this brew, lets see what it is like in two or three years.

( 12oz bottle) Clear red pour with nice soapy bubbles. Nose of oak, sour cherries, vanilla and saltiness. Taste of tart cherries/cranberries, nice carbonation and doesnt linger too tart at all. This is a super drinkable fruit sour.

12oz bottle.  thanks to beej for hooking me up with a couple bottles..... pours a strawberry blonde, with lively bottles, and a medium milky white head.... aroma of semi-sweet cranberries, apples, alongside a touch of vanilla and cinammon ... flavors of semi-sweet yet tart cranberry almost resembling the stuffing of a cranberry apple pie.  first sip had a little bit of metallicness to it but that diminished after subsequent sips.  prickly carbonation that cuts through some of the sweetness.  could be a little bit more on the sour/tart side but this is a tasty treat nonetheless.  incredibly drinkable and refreshing.

Bottle courtesy of Ughsmash. Pours a clear orange to copper color color with a massive white one finger head that settles slowly. Aroma is sweet and syrupy with notes of overripe fruit, honey, yeast, grain, caramel, fresh berries, hint of funky sourness. Flavor is sweet and floral with notes of ripe fresh fruit, honey, candy sugar, overripe cherries, nectar, vanilla, slight sour to tartness toward finish. Generally light to medium body with a sweet, syrupy and slightly tart finish. Nice.

12oz bottle, courtesy of MatSciGuy. Thanks, Levi! Pours a deep, medium pinkish-orange / ruby color; beautiful tint on this; thin off-white head with light retention and patchy, fine-bubbled lacing. Pleasant show of oily red fruits, very light tannins and grape skins, similar levels of diacetyl and softly toasted oak in the aroma; everything buttressed by a sparkling red berry character; similar to the Enigma, the light butter and vanilla-tinged oak (minimal overt wood) give this a touch of an overripe character; this is still quite lovely in the nose: great fruit, hints of cinnamon or clove as well. Medium mouthfeel: medium amounts of acidity, slightly oily character, and relaxed carbonation on this; somewhat slick feeling in the mouth; lots of red fruits (cherries, strawberries, cranberries) showing up here, with certainly a berry character overall, but it doesnt come across with quite the same sharp acidity or tannins of other cranberries beers that come to mind (there arent many); lively amounts of tartness, lightly soured and a very pleasant and clear show of the fruit in this; again, more mixed red fruits than cranberries alone, and theres a touch of purposeful diacetyl alongside toasted wood and light vanilla and grape skins; this has a lot of the same character as Enigma originally did in terms of the barrel notes and the slick feel in the mouth: similarly pleasant, but mixed with a melange of red fruits and hints of red wine character (from the tannins, of course, but even more than that); not my favorite New Glarus Unplugged, but definitely refreshing and showing an excellent fruit character. Lasting finish of oakiness and cinnamon and red berries; nice toastiness appears at the far end; balanced ending.

Finally! Big thank you to badbeer (Mike) for the 12oz bottle.  Clear bright orange with a one finger white head, fair retention.  The first few whiffs remind me of Enigma--not too sour, with moderate caramel sweetness.  Good amount of fruitiness that seems more like cherries and apple juice, and a little chocolate and leathery funk.  Faint spices (cinnamon), moderate oak influence noted.  Flavor has more sourness and the fruit does change somewhat though blindly, I dont think I could claim cranberry.  Fairly sweet, like all of NGs fruit beers.  Wheaty finish with bitterness at a 1-2, sourness at a 3 and oaky.  Moderate smooth carbonation with a medium body.  I miss you NG.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: What a pleasant surprise after my previous experience with a "Cranberry" "Lambic" that tasted like neither Cranberry nor Lambic.  While this is mild, it pretty much has to be as such by design.  Very tasty and refreshing.  Aroma is faint cranberry.  Appearance could pass for a higher end macro.  Taste is great, again subdued, and certainly leaning more sweet than sour.  Palate is perfectly carbonated and appropriately thin.  Overall, I cant wait until next season to trade for some more.

Huge thanks to MOTORTODDHEAD, this another awesome beer from NG, color is faint reddish with a white head. smells of sweet cranberry.  taste is cranberry upfront with a vinegary bite.  Verry sweet tasting too. carbination is perfect.  Has a nice woodsy aftertaste.  Great beer.  Thanks TODD
Bottle thanks to rciesla for sharing.Orange red pour with slight white head.  Sweet notes, cranberry,  ginger,fruits, grenadine. This is not a lambic! A mis named fruit beer perhaps but not a lambic.

A very straightforward but tasty lambic.  Not a lot of complexity and a bit thin on the tongue, but wonderful flavor.  Tart without being overpowering, the beer should be easily approachable by non-sour drinkers.

Bottle shared by beernbourbon at the ratebeer chicagoland tasting.  Thanks Vince!   Pours a pinkish red color with a small offwhite head.   smells like a  80% cherry or cranberry lambic 20% belgian red. tastes like 80 % belgian red 20% cherry/ cranberry fruit lambic.  Sticky mouthfeel.  This definitely wasnt bad, but if you are expecting  cantillon like acidity you will be let down.  Basically, It was dissapointing how sweet this was.  It wass good though, especially if you like fruit beers.

Beautiful red color. Excellent beer. Quite a bit of hay and barn in the aroma and flavor, tart but not all that sour. Really excellent balance though. Dry, but not super dry. Cranberries are awesome in this.

Bottle thanks to Sam Pours out a light pinkish looks kind of like wisky topped with no head. Aroma was very nice. Lots of berries, vanilla, and sweetness. Taste more of the berries and sweetness. Just the right amount of tart very tasty.
Bottle. Pours a very clear almost orange-amber. Very nice looking brew. Another fantastic fruit beer from New Glarus.

Sampled at the January 09 Metro Detroit tasting. Thanks to whoever brought this! Poured a clear light red with an orange tint. The head was off-white. Aroma had a bit of cranberry and a lot of tartness. Flavor started sweet with a bit of cranberry, the cranberry became more tart throughout for a nice finish.
Crushed with Honkeybra at GABF.  What is it your period?  Not much to say about this.  New Glarus makes the best fruit beers in the world and this one is stellar as well.

No other brewery makes fruit lambics quite like New Glarus. Pours a bright orange colour with lots of spritz, but no head. Aroma was fruity, very floral and cranberry filled with hints of oak and earth. Taste was tart, very fruitforward and incredibly tastey. It was hard to stop sipping it. Wicked tasty. Remembering the 77 Dead Cornell shows for my 1977 beer review."

Bottle shared at puzzls New Years Eve 2009: Blush colored pour with an off white head. Oaky aroma with some sweet, candied cranberry notes, though its not over the top sweet. Slick body with a mild tart fruitiness. Theres a soft candied presence from the cranberries. A tad thin and one dimensional. Falls very short of their Raspberry Tart and Belgian Red.

Bottle.  Poured light red with a medium white head leaving spotty lacing.  Nose is cranberry, wood, and light funk.  Medium body with a clean mouth feel and fizzy carbonation.  Taste is fairly sweet, pale malt up front which quickly gives way to some tart, oaky, cranberry and cherry notes.  Finishes with medium tartness.  New Glarus sure knows how to make a fruit beer.  Very good.
Bottle. Lots of cranberry with only soft notes of funk and yeast. Tartness levels seemed to be due to the nature of the cranberry not the beer. It was good, just a lot of cranberry for me to handle.

Bottle Clear amber ale with a fizzy, white head. Funky, fruity aroma. Full-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and tickling carbonation. Tart, fruity flavor  fuzzy fruit and berries. Sweet/tart finish. Bottle courtesy of smith4498!

Thanks Santa!  Pours looking like cherry 7-up with only a wisp of a slightly pink head.  A bunch of oakis the first thing I notice in the nose: rich round caramels, vanilla, honey.  While I wouldnt necessarily know the fruit here was cranberry it still smells damn good.  To me it seems more like a combination between cherries & strawberries.  There is a bit of tartness, but less than I expected - it is along the level of tartness that is found in their Belgian Red and Raspberry Tart.  When it hits my tongue I get more of that big oakey hit which quickly gives way to a slightly tart cherry, strawberry and red grape rush.  The tartness is a bit more pronounced here, and definitely recognizable as being sourced from cranberries.  The oak, tartness and sweeter fruit notes all mingle perfectly, creating a beverage that is as hard to pin down as NGs other fruit beers.  That of tannic zing that cranberries have comes out a bit in the finish, along with continuing fruit juice notes.  This is amazing stuff, and certainly in the same league as the Belgian Red & Raspberry Tart.  Carbonation is light but that works wonderfully here, leaving a really nice fruity finish.

Huge thanks to bman1113vr for sharing this bottle. Copper clear pour with a small white head. Aroma is sour, tart, oak, brett and cranberry. Flavor is lightly tart, slight cranberry, funk and a hint of yeastiness.

Bottle.  Very clear light strawberry colored pour with light lacing and little carbonation and a sour/fruity aroma.  Flavor is forward on the cranberry, raspberry and finished sweet and sour on the finish.  Very good, I wish there had been more bottles of this at Casanovas today!

Bottle from bonk0076.  Reddish-copper color that pours with a moderate sized off-white head with a slight shade of pink in there.  The aroma is somewhat funky with cranberries and caramel.  Tart cranberry flavor with soft velvety sweetness.  A little funk but not a lot.  Not as tart and sour as I was expecting.  In the same mold as Belgian Red and Raspberry Tart.  New Glarus doesnt mess up the fruit beers and heres another one thats very tasty and enjoyable.

Bottle thanks to FlssmrBrewAlum (thanks Adam!)  Pours a clear reddish-orange with a small white head.  Aroma of sour cranberry, sweettart candies, light mustiness, and oak.  Flavor is sour and tart initially with a sweet cranberry finish and some bready malt.  Lots of sweet cranberry.  Very little acidity.  Very similar to Belgian Red but with cranberries and slightly less sweetness.  Wow, what a great fruit beer!
9/5/9/5/18 [4.5/5]

Bottle courtesy of furley from TBS.  Guess I was a little underwhelmed with this one.  Smell was certainly fruity, and the taste was as well.  It seemed to me like a cross between a cherry lambic and ginger ale.  Very, very fizzy.  Not bad overall, but just kinda meh.

Bottle from Eugene. Clear reddish brown pour. Beery, malty aroma mostly, there is a touch of sucrose and sour in here but no noticeable cranberry. Cranberry once again fails to add anything to beer. The flavor is a little bit more balanced and to style, there is some mild balsamic vinegar-type acedic acid but still a lot of sugar, and maybe there is some cranberry here but it isnt very enjoyable. This is a rather unimpressive beer coming from Danny. He can do better.

Bottle from a trade with FlssmrBrewAlum. Pours light reddish orange color with white head. Fruity aroma with some oak. Light cranberry and oak flavor, tart with a touch of sweetness. Medium body with average carbonation. Thanks Adam.

12 oz bottle.  Clear pink bronze with a fluffy white head.  Nose is cranberry, lemon-lime, dough and mild funk.  Medium light with a faint tingle.  Taste is strawberry-vanilla yoghurt, candy apple and cinnamon.  Hints of cranberry add a slight sourness but nowhere near as tart as expected.  Very tasty but a bit too sweet and poppy for me.

Bottle shared by Bockyhorsey at the Black Friday tasting  thank Bill!  Pours clear reddish amber with a thin tan head.  The nose is wood, tart cranberries and sweet and sour cranberry sauce.  The taste is cranberry juice, oaky vanilla and tart berries.  Medium bodied.  Good stuff and another nice fruit beer from these guys.

Courtesy of markwise. Pours clear brilliant copper with thin off white head. The aroma is an even mix of fruity cherry, cranberry and currants mixing with some modest funk, tartness and a touch of sweet malts. The taste is smooth cherry to sweet cranberry goodness mixing with modest Brett like tartness and smooth yummy near chewy malt sweetness.

12  oz. bottle poured a very light pink like a white zinfendel with a orangeish hue,thin and sparkling, aromas are almost white wine like oak and fruits, taste is of cranberries,oak,and alcohol a very elagent beer can i say that any way it states from dan that this is brewed in the belguim lambic tradition so i have to ask why is this listed as a fruit and not a lambic

ORF release, Thanks for sharing!  Clear red pour with a fizzy pink head.  Aroma is vanilla and cranberry.  Flavor is lightly tart.  Decent brew, but more of a fruity ale then a lambic.  This beer had potential but just doesnt really deliver especially as a "lambic"
Bottle from Cavie.  Pours a weird orange with a thin head.  Aroma of hard liquor and wood barrels.  Tastes like bad whiskey and stale fruit.

Bottle courtesy of bonk0076, Clear orange pour. Bourbon aroma with a whisky smell. Very hard liquor-esque. Oaky flavor and smell. Taste has an aftertaste of soured apple. Everything improves until the finish. Dry to boot.
Bottle from Cavie.  I immediatly smell a barrel-aged whiskey scent.  The color is a light red, like many lambics.  The cranberry taste is light and not too offensive.
A nice lambic with a good tart flavor.  A smidgen of red across what would otherwise be a medium light amber coloring is a sign of whats to come.  Just a little foamy and spritzy. A nice one.

Bottle from StFun (thanks, Josh!) - man, they filtered the hell out of this - clear light red, fizzy - loads of cranberry in the nose, as well as a light funk, mild acidity, oak, vanilla - fairly sweet up front, with the cranberry taking center stage, with some vanilla oakiness propping it up - moderate acidity develops through the middle, seeming mostly acetic, but with a bit of lacto in there, too - builds to vinegary late, but the sweetness returns to counter it - strong cranberry throughout - there is some funkiness there, but mostly this beer tastes sterilized, dead - dont get me wrong, it tastes good, but in about six months, this beer is going to taste like ass.

Bottle pours red with a decent, but short lived head.  The aroma is of cranberry and slight sour funk.  The flavor is tart, cranberry, sour, and slightly funky.  The palate is effervescent and bright.  Overall, very nice.

A:  Pours a nice strawberry pink hue.  Small fizzy head.  No retention or lace.

S:  Nice fresh cut oak, tart berries, and fresh sweet cherry juice.  Nice sweet tart thing going here.

T:  There is nothing that New Glarus does bad.  Wow.  Light tart cranberry up front.  Sweet Belgian red cherry juice, and very very light oak.  No acid.

M:  On the lighter side, sweet and light tartness.

D:  Damn good.

Bottles courtesy of tjthresh and MrPickles - thanks, dudes! Pale pink pour with a frothy carbonation, or at least more pink and frothy than I expected. Soft barrel notes in the nose, very mellowed with a trace of vanilla. The berry is there ever so faintly in the aroma. Not really what Id expected given the style designation, but then again I give huge leeway to Mr. Carey. And in any case, Im a sucker for NGs barrel profile and the subtlety and depth it imparts to beers like these. Understated and dry for the most part, with a lingering woodiness that draws me in. Slight acidity in the finish but a beer thats unapologetically quirky, hybrid, and just plain delish.

This beer pissed me off, first the name cran-bic what else ends in bic lambic this is not even close to a lambic.  A crimson body with a thin pinkish white head.  Strawberries, jam, overtly sweet like grenadine, almost Shirley temple esk in sweetness. Fructose and other sweeteners.  Decent and thats it.

I was very surprised with this one.  Pours orange gold with bone white head.  Nose is oak, vanilla, brown sugar, fruit, and sweet cranberry.  Flavor is lots of cranberry sweetness, bite, cranberry sauce, vanilla, oak, and love.  Finishes really smooth with a minimum interference from wild yeast.  Excellent fruit beer from the guys who wrote the book on awesome fruit beers.
bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  red with a pink head. cranberries wood and vanilla on the nose.  very nice on the palate with a flavor of wood, cranberry and a slight tartness.  do want more

Wonderful sweet berry aroma with a hint of light sourness in the nose.  The pour is deep red with a decent head.  Full body and flavor with a good carbonation.  The flavor is quite a bit like Belgian Red, with a kick of acidity.  The oak comes through lightly in the background.  Easy to drink and very enjoyable flavor.

Poured from Bottle into Tumbler glass.

Pours a brilliant orange with pink highlights and a finger of fizzy tinted-white head that dissolves quickly into a thin layer that rests atop the glass. The aroma is tart cranberries, some wild yeast notes and maybe some hints of malt? The flavor is full of tart fruit, prickly fruit and just overall booming with cranberry. Its a light-medium bodied beer with a lively carbonation. This beer is really nicely done. I enjoy the cranberry which isnt overly pronounced but certainly is the center piece of this beer. Well Done.
Pours a nice red color with a little white head. Has a funky cranberry smell to it. Has a cranberry juice taste and is a little tart. Could be a little more tart for my liking.

Clear lifeless peach with no head.  Aroma of funk, cranberries, odd malt not a very strong aroma.  Taste of cranberries, oak, mild spices, malt and a touch of sulfur.  Semi-tart and sourness and a bit rough around the edges.  Finishes tart, then sweet.  Much like the Olde English Porter, I kept going back and forth on this one.

12 oz. pours crystal clear rubied amber. no head, lace, or legs. big tart cranberry nose with just the faintest whisper of funk around it. creamy medium body, very light carb. big tart and tangy cranberry mid palate thats really all fruit. any yeast or lacto is just there to magnify the fruit. could arguably be a lot more complex, but the fruit flavor is so fresh and developed that theres no reason to miss it.

Bottle thanks to St. Fun. Pours with a fading white head over a reddish body. Aroma of cranberry juice, oak and tartness. Ocean spray cranberry juice. Taste is bretty, light vanilla and wood. Some tartness but not tart enough...age it another two years ;) Lively carbonation. Dry.

Sample at the ORF tasting.  Poured a cloudy orange with a small white head.  Definitely cranberry in the aroma and some grain.  Taste was sour sour sour cranberry tart with some other citric sourness coming through.  Great beer. Loved the sourness

12oz. bottle with a big thank you to Beastiefan2k for hauling this back for me from the great North.  Pours a clear rose-ish orange with a moderate white head that settles to a whispy covering.  Aroma is cran-tastic (oh, man I just couldnt help that one), with fresh and tart cranberries, oak, other berries, and some yeastiness.
