Flavor is nicely tart and fresh, with more cranberry, oak, mixed berry, a little vanilla, and just enough sweetness to demand repeated sips.  Nice stuff, just wishing the "wild" qualities would be there to have more of a lambic thing going on.

12oz bottle shared at the DC local tasting.  Pours a totally transparent slightly rosy amber with a thin, ringing white head.  Tart aroma, some wheat and grass.  Flavor is tart, cranberries, puckering strawberries.  Finish is lasting tartness, heavy carbonation.

12oz Bottle. Thanks John! A funky, juicy aroma, filled with freshly grated jicama, tangerine, and lime juice. Very soft, forward with fruit, picking up nice fall bog cranberries, and mingled red fruit sweetness. Intoxicating. Pours a bubbly very clear and surprisingly pale deep rose, moving from ochre at the fringes to florid in the center. A thin white rim. Flavor is somehow less satisfying than the aroma let on. Still good, but not as dense as I expected. Gentle cereal-sweetness, a splash of cranberry sauce, and some lambic bottle dregs. This has a very pillowy fruit character that immediately reminds me of Belgian Red. In reality, this beer really is like a blend of Belgian Red, Enigma, and the Berliner Weisse. The house character is strong. The dimensions are all nice, but a little shallow. It must be really light on the alcohol, because it tastes much like sparkling raspberry-apple cider. Really, though, should this have been filtered?

A pretty good sour ale.  Pours a clear reddish amber with almost no head to speak of and an aroma of tartness and fruit.  The flavors range from fruity sweet in the beginning to oak, honey, vanilla and a culmination of lovely tartness at the end.  This was surpisingly good, and I really look forward to trying more of the Unplugged series.

12oz bottle, thanks ygtbsm94.  Small off-white head atop crystal clear red-orange body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, cranberry, some lemon, funk.  Taste is moderately sweet, cranberry, some funk, lemon.  Light-medium body.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2010 Sampled at the ORF pre-release tasting. Pours a cloudy orangish pink (?) with a white head. Nose is tart cranberries, cranberry skins, some barnyard funk, earth. Taste is similar: very tart, lactic, sour cranberries, some wild farmhouse notes, oak. It is really unique and enjoyable. I was so excited to try this. Now I just want more! 12/13/2009 8/4/8/5/15=4.0
355mL courtesy of CaptainCougar. Pours a clear orange slight pink with a billowing off-white head. Big retention and lots of lace everywhere. Aroma is creamy fruits, raspberry cheesecake, mint, slight phenol character. Very different from when I tasted this fresh. Taste is on the sweet side, lots of creamy fruits like Belgian Red or Raspberry Tart, slight tartness. Creamy palate. Pretty good but aging this has really drained the sourness. 9/30/2010 6/5/7/4/14=3.6

Very accessible but not a session ale.  Distinct cranberry flavor doesnt overwhelm ale flavor.   Not too sweet like most lambics and it sweetness perfectly balance out the tartness. Filtered. NGs best fruit brew so far. Filtered with cut pink look

Traded botte. Man this made me happy. Words for other folks: crisp, oaky, cranberry sublties in the colour and tart/sour flavour. Since this is my rating: this was like Ernie opening a bottle of reisling from 1974. That same, unidentifiable taste. I need more of this.

12 oz bottle

Thanks to Jason for sending me two four packs of this.  It will be tough not to drink them in quick succession since this tastes like a fabulous blend of Enigma, Raspberry Tart, and cranberry relish.  This might just go down as the best Unplugged entry to date.  Clearly the Careys have not lost their touch; I cannot wait to see what comes out of the new building in 2010.

Aroma / Appearance - Looking like carbonated cranberry juice the short lived dirty white head glimmers in the daylight.  Sour and tart like Enigma with a few months on it this has a background of cranberry.  Sweetness accents the sour aspect which is a bit like either Belgian Red or Raspberry Tart in nature.

Flavor / Palate - Fruity brown cedar snaps the palate awake.  Sour like a Flemish brown it brings to memory previous entries such as Sour Brown and Enigma in the way it fills the mouth with a wonderful woody texture.  Thick but not cloying it is nice to sit on this one for a while just savoring the experience.  This is the perfect Thanksgiving / Christmas seasonal.  Stock up while you can; this one should be good for a couple of years to come.

Bottle from secret santa...thanks alot. Poured a nice dark red color with nothing for a head. Aroma is funky, fruity, sour, oak. Taste is nice and sour. Lots of dry fruit...alittle cranberry...funk, some oak. Very nice on the palate. Nice after taste.....lots of fruit. Very enjoyable.

Thanks turdferguson for sharing. Pours a sharp translucent orange copper with a one finger crackling white head. The nose is tart, shows cranberry skins, a mild sweetness, definitely some funk, yogurty/lactic character, big pie spice character. Flavor shows a restrained tartness and acidity, cranberry, sweet character, yogurty, mild funk. Palate shows a mild tartness with low carbonation and a creamy coating character. Tasty but not super complex.

Bottle. Pour is a clear ruby. Aroma is of tart cranberries, brett, aged cheese straw, and earthy characters. Flavor is very well balanced and quite complex with sweet cranberry, more brett, cheese. This was a real treat. I cant find anything wrong with this.

12 oz bottle graciously purchased for me by beastiefan2k. Pour is clear ruby golden with a white-pinkish fluffy one inch head. Aroma is musty cranberry (peels and the fruit) along with a good dose of oak barrel. Some nice soft vanilla notes are in there as well. Nice nose. Taste is the sweet, semi tart fruit of the cranberry up front, followed by the oak and vanilla notes from the nose. The fruit is the main story, and it is very natural and clean.  The palate is medium, with a fair amount of spritzy carbonation. The finish is long with the cranberry fruit and then the vanilla oak. Hiding behind that in the finish is some brief yeastiness, though quite subdued.  This beer is quite refreshing, though I was expecting a bit more in the yeastiness department. Thanks for grabbing this and bringing it back for me Eugene.

12oz bottle shared by photomike.   Pink color with a medium head.   Looks like a fizzy white zinfandel.   What does this beer smell like?  Hmm, um, sweet bread with cranberry jam on it.   Sounds about right.   Maybe some spice in there too, but the jam is strong with this one, not unlike some other fruit beers by NG, though it isnt as strong in intensity.   Lots of cranberry in the flavor, but actually less tart than cranberry juice, though not as sweet either.   The balance actually leans toward sweetness vs. tartness, but has some cinnamon and malt to break it up and finishes wothout too much sweetness.   Medium-light body with medium carbonation.   A hell of a lot better than another American brewers lambic which shall not be named here, but still nothing like an actual lambic.

Pours an appealing ruby orange color with a small frothy white head. Aroma is cranberry juice. Period. Flavor is similar. Blackberries and cherries with a distinctive cranberry tartness in the finish. New Glarus manages to make another beer that tastes exactly like a fruit. Awesome.

courtesy of markwise. Cheers for bringing this gem. NG has done it again.
pours amber, thin white head.
aroma, nice wood/oak, hints of red fruits/berries, cranberry and deep fruit tartness.
flavor, similar to aroma, just exceptional blend between the wood/oak, cranberry/light vanilla adding a nice bourbon like palate. Hints of fruit tartness that seems to be attenuated by the wood. Light hints of malt, and possibly some yeast with a wonderful tart cranberry finish.
Not much else to say, exceptionally easy to drink and well crafted.
Definitiely exhibits a lambic taste and texture, but not much more.  I cant taste the cranberry in this beer, but it does share all other characteristics of a good lambic.  Average.

Bottle shared with Croslig and rye726 poured a clear pinkish amber with a lingering ring of pink foam. Aromas of cranberry, barnyard, light leather and vanilla. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a smooth finish. Flavors of cranberry, vanilla, barnyard and light leather with a smooth lightly funky finish. Tastey brew but would be better with some tartness.

12oz bottle served in a shaker.  Clear cranberry skin hued pour with a few golden brown highlights and a thin head of pinkish-tan foam that hung around for a bit.  Minimal lacing.  The aroma included fresh cranberries, fruit pits, oak, sour fruits, and a hint of vinegar.  The flavor was very nice.  Loaded with fresh cranberry notes and a woody sourness.  Definitely not a traditional lambic, as this was just mildly sour with a decent amount of sweetness.  Think of it as a cranberry fruit beer with an afterthought of sourness.  Medium-bodied with a light amount of crisp carbonation.  This would be a nice addition to their other year round fruit beers.

Pours a murky purple/red. Nose is huge fruit, cranberries, tart and sweet berries. Flavor is the signature giant fresh fruit that New Glarus is known for. Big tart berry, sour berry, mild funk, lactic sourness, dry earthy wood notes. Absolutely fanastic!

Bottle thanks to MatSciGuy.  Pour is deep brownish red with a very small head.  Aroma is bourbon, vanilla, dark berry, light funk, and cranberry.  Flavor is initially sour and funky, then the sweetness and tartness of the cranberry come through.  Next the beer dries out for a moment before transitioning into a finish that has both vanilla silkiness and light cranberry tartness.  Also a light sweetness in the finish. Three distinct acts with very smooth transitions.  Quite complex and really impressive.  Im not a huge fruit beer fan, but I can certainly respect the craftsmanship of this brew.

Beautiful pale pink pour.  Aroma is very fruity, as is the flavor.  Rather sweet and medium tart with a distinct strawberry (I know, should be cranberry!) flavor to it.  Notes of cream / butter round it out a bit.  Quite good.

Bottle courtesy of CanIHave4Beers.  Pours light clear orange with pink tint and a lovely foamy little white head.  Nose provides quite a bit of cranberries -- more than expected. Oak behind the fruit as well, but it comes out more in the flavor, which starts out tart but provides more oaky complexity.  Lively palate. Unique, and quite nice.

Bottle. Poured a clear ruddy orange color. The head was two fingers high and white. Smelled of fruit and spices. Almost like a cran-apple cider. Medium bodied and sweet. Tasted very similar to apple cider with cranberries and mulled wine. There were also notes of pale malt and light caramel. A bit too sweet for me, but an interesting beer.

Thanks for dropping a bottle off, bro!  Pours a crisp pinkish-bronze color with a medium frothy white head which fades to a thin pinkish hue, leaving plenty of webbed lacing.  Aroma is cranberries,  watermelon jolly rancher, and cinnamon oak amalgamation.  Taste is sugary sweet cranberries, medium carbonation, and then fades rather clean with some nice oak and cinnamon coming out.  Very good, although I wish it was a bit more carbonated and sour.  My brother was right, its almost like a combination between Belgian Red and Enigma - although Id probably prefer this to either of those.

Bottle provided by the BockyHorseys...THANKS BILL AND WENDY!!!  Great unique beer that pours from the bottle a vibrant crimson and creates a small ivory head that leaves only a touch of lacing.  Aroma is Thanksgiving...with tart cranberry taking the show.  Wood, balsamic, cherry skins, and even vanilla are present.  Flavor is sour but not jaw locking.  Cranberry, brown sugar, oak, and lemon find the tongue.  Ample carbonation makes this extremely drinkable.  Nicely done.

Bottled.  Poured crystal-clear lighter orange with a short cap of whitish head.  The aroma picked up tart cranberries, lemony vinegar, and dry funk, with the cranberries really leading the charge.. some fruity softness cut through the sourness just the right way.. excellent!  The flavor found pale malts and dusty cranberry at the core, with tart cranberry skins and oaky bitterness around.. a touch sweeter than expected on the finish, but it was still mighty tasty.  Light-medium bodied and well-carbonated on the palate.. tart, engaging, and well-balanced.. Im going to drink a lot of these.

Bottle courtesy of mother in law. Good cranberry fruty aroma along with some sour on the nose. Red body with not much of head. Cranberry flavor thoughout beer with a real tart sour bitter bit in the end. Another good carbinated fruit beer from Wis. that gives you aroma and flavor of fruit start to finish of beer.

Pours a rich rose color with thin light pink head.  Aroma is of sour yeast, ripe fruit, cranberry, oak and vanilla.  Taste is tart fruit up front which gives way to a sweet fruit, tangy cranberries, and if left to warm, you get a nice oak flavor which leaves the tongue with a nice flavor of vanilla.  Carbonation is well appointed (moderate) and the sourness of the yeast and the tang of the cranberry are very well balanced.  Another fine fruit beer from Dan Carey.

Appearance:  Pours a rose pint with a small white head. The body is clear.

Aroma:  Raspberry, cranberry and ever so slight funk.

Taste: Cranberry, raspberry, brown sugar, lemon and some industrial yeast notes.

Mouthfeel:  Fizzy and puckering.

Overall:  Unbelievably awesome. I hope this is made again, and Id love to see it in the 750ml bottle like Wisconsin Red.
12 oz bottle from Chicones.  Reddish/amber pour with no head.  Fruity, somewhat sour aroma with a sweet/tart cranberry flavor.  Reminds me of champagne.  Sweet finish.

Clear, dark red color with a very small and fizzy head.  Strong malt aroma, with a lot of dried cranberries.  Some wheat.  The sweet malt base is very delicious, quite complex.  Caramel.  Tart cranberries with a few touches of sour.  After warming up, an old French oak character comes out with a bit of vanilla.  This one flippin rocks.
pale pink aroma of cranberry malt flavor cranberry malt tart sourness sweeness. nice brew thanks bockys
So pretty! Pink-red-yellow clarity. And delicious! Sweet and sour and bubbly-light on the tongue with slight funk, some lemon, a bit of  cran bitterness. Plus some deep woodiness.

12 oz. bottle from tjthresh as part of the NP10v4.  Pours a clear cranberry red with a thin white head slightly tinted pink.  There is a stream of tiny bubbles continuously rising to the surface.  This beer really looks beautiful in the glass.  Very pleasant aroma of cranberry along with some mild oak and just a bit of funk.  The flavor is both tart and sweet with cranberry, a bit of lemon, mild oak and just a bit of funk. Bright and lively on the palate.  Simply put, this beer is a delight.

(bottle) Pours light brownish-red with a white head and good lacing.  Aroma is slightly musty, but when swirled more of the tart and sweet cranberry is displayed.  A little bit of oak and vanilla is present as well, but not too complex on the nose.  Taste is very good, with a nice balance between sweet and tart, a lot of cranberry flavor and lemon zest, which yields to a subtle oak and earthy undertone on the finish.  Mouthfeel is medium and the carbonation is lively.  Not terribly complex, but its very drinkable and tasty nonetheless.
ruby red pour, no head...nose is sweet, fruity...flavor is sweet upfront and tart in the finish...flavors are really mellowed by the oak

aroma is stench of tart cranberries and gigantic wood. appearance is wonderfully translucent light red bordering on regular old amber.  flavor is a blast of wood and cranberry simultaneously, so that no pure ocean spray style juice flavor ever shows its face alone. hit of sourness and funk appears in the aftertaste, subtle and fleeting. wood muck lingers for a good while must to my enjoyment.  no cloying fruit sweetness, no overwhelming fruit character or fruit juice type of approach. big big wood and just a classy hit of sourness.

12 oz bottle from Roys Market (New Glarus, WI). Pours a bit of a reddish gold, tinged with the brighter berry touch, really quitw taken by the hue, very faint haze, well carbonated, decent white head that dies to a small film, clings to the edges. Aromas are some nice wet wood, tart cranberries, dry oak, a touch of champagne and light malty sweetness. A touch of vanilla, faint spice, the cranberry comes in a bit, tart yet mildly sweet. Initial is a wonderful balance of cranberry and lighter grainy sweetness, a touch of honey and vanilla, almost yogurt with a nice light sourness, subtle and smooth, moving into an enjoyable tartness that sticks to the palate, good carbonation on the palate, sourness grows a bit as I get further in, but it certainly is balanced with good sweetness, as cranberry really makes the nature of this beer, tart and sweet in harmony. Dry, a touch prickly. I liked this, but interested to see what kind of dying out of the fruit and dryness this beer might get with age. Very nice, a subtle sour fruit beer, more delicate but layered flavors.

Wonderful fruity tartness and sourness in aroma,sure could be cranberry, my mouth waters just smelling it as my jowls anticipate the sourness. Taste,wow that sure is sweet, not as tart or sour as the aroma leads you to believe it would be. plenty of sucker like cherry/cranberry sweetness. Some oak shows up in the aftertaste,medium body a little to much emphasis on the sweetness,could use a little more sourness in flavor to be more like a true lambic. Mostly a desert or summer sipper

Bottle:  The aroma consists of cranberries, cherries, and oak.  It pours a transparent amber with a small white head.  The flavor starts with cranberry.  Theres a nice oak presence throughout.  The finish has some mild sour cherry tartness.  Medium bodied with soft carbonation.  Not a lambic, but a very nice fruit beer.

Bottle shared by Josh.  Thanks Josh!  Pours clear cherry red color with white head.  Aroma is sweet cranberry juice.  Tingly mouthfeel.  Flavor is cranberry juice with with an ever so slight tartness to it.  This was a nice effort.  A little too sweet for my liking.  But a nice effort.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2011 Pours a light pinkish-red, with light head. Aroma is fresh and crisp and fruity. Flavor is sweet with just a very light touch of sour cranberry. Very refreshing and interesting beer.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2010 12oz bottle.  Light  filtered pink-orange color.  Mellow cranberry aroma.  Solid cranberry and Brett taste.  Very light and easy drinking, which is very true to style I suppose.  A little light in the ABV department and very sweet, a slightly better version of all the cheaper Belgian fruit Lambics, albeit with that rugged test tube sourness.  The sour aftertaste really sticks with you.  A pretty cool addition to the New Glarus fruit beer family.  addendums : I recently had this on tap and liked it  even more.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2011 [rated 11.18.09]  12oz bottle.  Pours a clear glowing... well... cranberry juice color with a nice thick frothy white foam.  Aroma is strong lactic, yogurt, saw dust, some cranberry, but overall thats a hard aroma to place, mostly lightly tart yogurt, similar to some of Uplands lambics in aroma.  Flavor at first is sharp and very tart crisp cranberry, very bright, immediately followed by smooth yogurt and cedar, finishing like cranberry yogurt, very nice, quick finish with a tart and quite sour aftertaste, leaves nice sourness on the gums.  Medium bodied with very sharp and crisp sizzling carbonation.  7.5.8.4.16.  . . . . . . . . . . . . [bottle 6.8.10]  Pours a cranberry color that seems to have faded slightly to now include orange brown notes, still with thick frothy white head.  Aroma is more of saw dust, very woody.  Flavor is still quite sweet of cranberries but seems to have gotten a bit more tart, cedar, light yogurt, great cranberry flavor, finishes candy like.   I cant tell if I like it more or less now, but I suppose Ill rate it more conservatively this time out.  8.4.7.4.15 ...... [several bottles served in 2011.... man its really come around... freakin delicious now... what a masterpiece!!! 8.5.8.4.17]

12 ounce bottle thanks to MatSciGuy, thanks a ton man. Pours a clear golden color with hints of red, a medium white head. The aroma is sweet woody oak, loads of cranberries. The flavor is great; a explosion of smooth and sweet oak, vanilla, earthy flavors, then the fresh and superb cranberries kick in-  a wonderful mix. Unique, the wood really comes out, smooth and rich berries mix in so well. Lovely.

12oz bottle shared thanks to the other Tom. Poured a medium reddish/orange color, clear, and with almost no head. Aromas of caramel, some cranberries, some woodiness, and cherry pie. Tastes of berries, cranberries, and lighter breadiness. Starts of sweet and ends lightly tart.

Bottle: Pours a bright pinkish orange with a spotty-lacing forth of white head.  Aroma abounds with fresh tart cranberries and buttery, woody oak along with some light horseblanket funk.  Starts with a soft pale malty sweetness with good fruit balance and lots of tart oaky flavor before a slightly puckering drier finish.  Reminds me a light of their Unplugged Enigma with a lighter fruit character.  Good complexity throughout and should age very well.  A great beer and a steal for the price.

Bright red color with a pink head.  Aroma is sweet oak cranberries.  Flavor is the gem here with a nice tartness to balance out the sweetness of the beer.  Finish is very dry and leaves the sourness of the beer on your palate.  Excellent beer.  Not quite better than the Belgian Red, but I would put it above the Raspberry Tart.

Beautiful red pour with light white head.  Aroma of carnberries, earthy yeast, funk.  Flavor of tart cranberries, some cherry,  A bit of puckering lactic sourness.  Finishes sour.  Finishes nice and dry.  Another excellent fruit beer from New Glarus.

Just saw this at the store and bought in a 4-pack.  Pours a light red with less than a finger of head; keeps a light lacing throughout the beer.  Nose is floral with fruit.  Taste is delicious - a very good lambic.  Not too sweet, but not exceedingly tart as might be expected from a cranberry beer.  A hint of oak in the flavor as well.  Very good.

Pink gold with a small, white head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of wild yeast, cranberries, wood, vanilla, and toast.  Taste of tart cranberry skins, cherry pit, bread, and a tart finish.  Similar to the other NG fruit beers, thanks warriorsoul!

Thanks to warriorsoul for sharing this one. Pours a pinkish golden with little to no head.  Aroma of tart cranberry, candy sugar, cherries reminds me a lot of the Belgian Red, but with cranberry!  Aroma was also a lot like the Belgian Red. Tart cherry and cranberry, pie crust, like oak notes, some vanilla and a touch of some sour notes.

Pours golden strawberry with pink head.  Aroma is a combination of oak and flowers, with a hint of cranberry.  Sour and dry cranberry, with some sweetness and oak.  Not overpowering, but definately not lacking impact.

2009 Bottle - Thanks motortoddhead!! - Pours a beautiful clear, dark pink with a small pink head that dissipates quickly...aroma is oaky and fruity, cranberry and cherry...flavour is gorgeous, dry cranberries and cherries, heavy vanilla oak and slightly sweet honey...dont expect an ass-puckering lambic cause this aint it, but it walks a great line alternating between sweet and tart...terrific beer...I could drink them all...

12 ounce bottle from New Glarus.  Pours brown with a bit of a red tint.  A short lived fizzy head formed but has long since passed.  The nose is rich with ripe tart cranberries, and a robust oak character.  Very full and complex fruit and barrel flavor with plenty of sprite carbonation and a mild dry finish.  This one here is a winner.

Wow.  Mellow, dreamy but still biting and punchy.  As lambics go, the cranberry factor is BRILLIANT.  Tart, potently yeasty, it smacks around the palate.  Not only that, but the color is incredible.  You just have to keep staring at this beer (pick a nice glass) because it fits so amazingly the autumn-rich / fruit-potency of the flavor.  So very unique - - a mind-blowingl conflagration of style, care, skill, and ingredient.

Light amber with a hint of pink color. Moderate off-pink head. Sweet malt and berries mingle with a straightforward lambic essence (mix of barn and attic). Quite sweet in the front, with berries all over the place. Soft and creamy feel. Light acidity creeps in near the finish and into the linger. Some light oak and citrus also in the linger. Very easy drinking. Another great fruit brew for NG. Look forward to seeing how this one ages.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2011 This is friggin delicious! Red pour.  Very light pink head.  Aroma is sweet/tart.  Honey,cranberries, loads of oak and some lemony notes.  Flavor is sweet and tart.  Just like good cranberry sauce.  Lemony, oaky and awesome.
Pours red with a tan head.  Smells of pronounced cranberries, some dry malty hints.  Tastes of tarte cranberries, some lactic hints, some earthy undertones, lightly peppery.

Pours a clear, rose-tinted amber with a short-lived, scant white head. Instant whiff of cranberries upon opening the bottle. This fades quickly to be replaced by a sweet, creamy wild yeast funk. Initially tart flavor, fruity, but anything distinctly of cranberry is very subdued. Wild yeast slowly takes over the flavor with undertones of chocolate and cheese. Finishes sweet. Medium body, strongly mouthcoating. Light warmth and sparkle.

Pours a brilliant rose color with a big fluffy white head and a pretty lace. There are lots of champagne like bubbles in the glass. The aroma is mildly funky with some sweat and some pronoucned sweet fruitiness. The flavor is tart and mildly sour with a lot of cranberry and sour cherry flavors, this is complimented but a mild nuttiness. The beer is delicious but its a tad sweet to my tastes. Thoes who like Beglian Red will no doubt like this.

Sampled from 12-oz bottle, shared by MatSciGuy during Darkness Day 2009 in Brooklyn Center, MN. Pours a semi-hazy amber red colored brew with a hot pinkish white head that has some nice retention. Aroma of tart red berries, a hint of yeast and some barnyard funk. Taste is nicely balanced between tart and sweet berries/cranberries with some yeast and earth herbs in the background. Finish is slightly tart with some cranberry and yeast aftertaste. A tad lighter than the Belgian Red and not as tart as the Raspberry Tart.

This stuff was amazing, thanks to Levi once again.  Pour was a beauty gold red.  Aroma was that of cranberries, cherries.  Flavor is wonderfully sour and semisweet.  Palate is tart, perfectly carbonated.  Overall this is great but compared to the Belgian Red, not quite there.

Bottle - Pours rosy copper with a white head. Smells a lot like NG Belgian Red -- the cranberries smell sweet and practically hit you from across the room. Theres actually some cherry smell in there too. Not sure what thats about. Theres a bit of tart, but mostly its sweet. Taste is more tart, with a little sourness on the finish. Itll be interesting to see if this dries out over time, because its pretty sweet now. Its a bit syrupy, but the velvety carbonation makes for a nice mouthfeel. Superb.

Thanks to MatSciGuy.  A brownish red with minimal head.  Tart aroma with plenty of cranberry character.  A little sour in there with a lactic character.  A sweet cranberry body with faint sourness and tartness on the finish.

Off golden pour, big white well laced head.  Huge fruit forward aroma smells much sweeter than cranberries like rasberry tart w/ more sugars but fades quickly.  AGressively carbonated palate, well coated.  Great flavor sweet cranberries in the front, w/ just enough tartness in the swallow to even it out another fruit dominated beer w/ some dry wood in the finish.  Very nice.

GABF 2009.  This owns, albeit to a lesser extent than the cherry and raspberry beers.  Brilliant clear dark red color with a small but lasting white head.  Aroma is lots of cranberries, tart and sweet, oak, and just a touch of funk.  Flavor is nice intense cranberries and oak, with the sweetness balanced with a cranberry tartness and some earthy notes.  Palate is smooth and medium-bodied with a little tart bite.  New Glarus just kills fruit beers.  Kills em.

9/28/09 notes: poured at GABF.  Pours dark red and clear.  Nose has soft acidity, cranberry and lemon.  Flavor hits with a MUCH more balanced semi-sweetness than either Belgian Red or Raspberry Tart, there is even a little bite from real cranberries.  A balanced, semi-sweetned lambic.  Some earthy notes towards the finish, layered nicely with tartness and cranberries.  I would have preferred this with more sour punch, but I quickly realized this wasnt New Glarus goal with this beer.

GABF 2009.  Pours clear amber with a small, frothy white head, mostly diminishing with spare lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (bread, hay, straw, cereal), average hop (flowers), average yeast (earth) with notes of cranberries.  Light bodied, slick texture, average carbonation, and an astringent finish.  Average duration, light sweetness, moderate acidity and sourness; a tad tart.
